thread.title: Intelligence Report Claims Putin Ordered Efforts To ‘Harm’ Hillary’s Presidential Campaign
thread.title_full: Intelligence Report Claims Putin Ordered Efforts To ‘Harm’ Hillary’s Presidential Campaign

author: Andrew Kerr
title: Intelligence Report Claims Putin Ordered Efforts To ‘Harm’ Hillary’s Presidential Campaign

organizations.name: presidential campaign trump meets with editors of vanity fair

text:
Trump Meets With Editors Of Vanity Fair, Other Critics 
The report states that Russia was anticipating a Clinton win in the lead up to the election. “When it appeared to Moscow that Secretary Clinton was likely to win the election, the Russian influence campaign then focused on undermining her expected presidency,” the report says. 
The administration claims that Putin’s motivation to wage this disinformation campaign was because he holds a “grudge” against Clinton for disparaging comments against the Russian president and her efforts to incite “mass protests against his regime in late 2011 and early 2012.” 
Furthermore, Russia developed a clear preference for Trump, and saw an opportunity in teaming up with Trump “as a way to achieve an international counterterrorism coalition against the Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIL).” Advertisement - story continues below 
Russia’s campaign was multifaceted, the report says. In addition to engaging in cyber espionage against U.S. political organizations, Russia also engaged in “overt efforts by state-funded media, third-party intermediaries, and paid social media users or ‘trolls.'” 
The report, released to the public, is a highly declassified version of the one prepared for government officials. The conclusions of this report are “identical” to those in the classified assessment, but does not include all supporting information on key elements of Russia’s influence campaign. 
After being briefed by intelligence leaders on the report, Trump said Russia’s hacks had “absolutely no effect on the outcome of the election.” 
Trump went a step further in an interview Friday with the New York Times, calling the allegations “a political witch hunt.” Advertisement - story continues below
